list.title: Question 1
list.content:
What provides evidence that all life on Earth evolved from the same population of cells?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Both mitochondria and prokaryotes have a cell wall.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Both eukaryotes and bacteria contain histones.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	The genetic code is universal.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
All 64 codons of the genetic code are present in all organisms, apart from minor variations indicating that all life evolved from the same original cells  (Choice D).
Eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells (Choice A) is incorrect as this is the endosymbiotic theory. Choice B is incorrect as mitochondria do not have a cell wall. Choice C is incorrect as bacteria do not have histones.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
What is the main role of the ribosomes labelled in the micrograph?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/27f4e9b2-a827-45ea-adaa-3d1c5221f126/images/9ecd433c-f10b-472c-93ea-f2ada27190ee/rough%20endoplasmic%20reticulum%20RER%20rough%20ER.png)


[Adapted from OpenStax. (2016, May 18). File:0313 endoplasmic reticulum B en.png - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 1, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:0313_Endoplasmic_Reticulum_b_en.png. Copyright free]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Synthesise enzymes to be used within the cytoplasm
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Transport mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Destroy proteins that the cell no longer needs
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Synthesise proteins for use in lysosomes
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Bound ribosomes synthesise proteins for secretion outside of the cell, membrane-associated proteins or proteins used in lysosomes (Choice D).
While ribosomes do synthesize enzymes, the ribosomes attached to the rough ER specifically target the proteins they synthesize for secretion or for use in membrane-bound organelles (like lysosomes) or the cell membrane, rather than for immediate use within the cytoplasm. Proteins meant to function within the cytoplasm are typically synthesized by free ribosomes that are not attached to the rough ER. Choice A  is incorrect. 
Choice B  is incorrect as bound ribosomes do not transport mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. 
Choice C  is incorrect as ribosomes do not destroy proteins.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A strand of nucleotides reads CCUAGAGCUUACCG. Which type of pentose sugar could be found in the nucleotides in the natural composition of this strand?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Deoxyribose only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Ribose only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Both deoxyribose and ribose
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Neither deoxyribose nor ribose
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The nucleotide strand CCUAGAGCUUACCG contains the bases cytosine (C), uracil (U), adenine (A), and guanine (G). While C, A, and G are found in both DNA and RNA, the base uracil is only found in RNA. So, the strand is an RNA strand.
RNA contains the pentose sugar ribose. Therefore, ribose is found in the nucleotides in the strand.
Choices A and C are incorrect because deoxyribose is only found in DNA, not RNA. The nucleotide strand cannot be DNA because it contains uracil in place of thymine (T).
Choice D is incorrect because the strand is RNA which contains ribose.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Which statement is correct concerning the structure of DNA?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ A phosphate within a nucleotide is covalently bonded to a nitrogenous base
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ DNA molecules are made up of two parallel strands running in the same 3'-5' direction, linked by hydrogen bonds between complementary bases
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Bonding between adjacent phosphates and deoxyribose sugars forms the backbone of DNA
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Adenine is complementary to uracil, and cytosine is complementary to guanine
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Covalent bonding between adjacent phosphates and deoxyribose sugars forms the backbone of DNA; Choice C is correct.
Within nucleotides, the phosphate is covalently bonded to the deoxyribose sugar and the sugar is attached to the base; Choice A  is incorrect. DNA molecules are made up of two antiparallel strands (they are parallel but run in opposite directions, one runs 3’-5’ and the other 5’-3’), linked by hydrogen bonds between complementary bases; Choice B  is incorrect. In DNA, adenine is complementary to thymine; Choice D  is incorrect.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
What distinguishes uracil from thymine?


UracilThymineA.$\hspace{1em}$Joined to a pentose sugarJoined to a hexose sugarB.$\hspace{1em}$Found in RNAFound in DNAC.$\hspace{1em}$Two-ring structureSingle-ring structureD.$\hspace{1em}$Complementary to cytosineComplementary to adenine
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Uracil and thymine are nitrogenous bases found in two types of nucleic acids: DNA and RNA.
Uracil is found in RNA, whereas thymine is found in DNA. (Choice B)
In RNA, Uracil is not complementary to cystine, it is complementary with adenine, and thymine is also complementary to adenine
(Choice D).
In both DNA and RNA, these nitrogenous bases are joined to a five-carbon sugar, also called a pentose sugar which has a ring structure, so Choice A is incorrect.
Both uracil and thymine are pyrimidines which are single-ring structures (Choice C). Adenine and guanine are purines which consist of two rings.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Which statements are characteristics of a DNA molecule?



- I.The two strands are identical.II.The two strands are antiparallel to one another.III.The sugar-phosphate backbone is held together by covalent bonds.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
A DNA molecule is made up of two antiparallel strands of nucleotides. Antiparallel means that both strands are geometrically parallel but oriented in opposite directions (Option II). One of the strands is in the direction of 5' to 3', whereas the other strand is in the direction of 3' to 5'. The backbones, made of alternating sugar and phosphate groups, are held together by covalent sugar-phosphate bonds (Option III). Both of these strands are joined together by the hydrogen bonds between the complementary base pairs.
DNA strands are not identical (Option I) because identical would mean that they have the same nucleotide arrangement, instead they are complementary to each other.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Which of the following processes is most directly involved in the formation of nucleic acids such as DNA?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Hydrolysis
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Condensation
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Catabolism
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Translation
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Nucleotides are linked together by condensation reactions to form molecules of DNA (Choice B). The formation of DNA requires the removal of water for the joining of smaller molecules to form a larger molecule.
The joining of nucleotides together can also be classified as an anabolic reaction but not as a catabolic reaction (Choice C). Catabolism is the breaking down of a large molecule into a smaller molecule. An example of catabolism is hydrolysis which is a reaction that breaks down a large molecule into a smaller molecule by adding water (Choice A).
Translation is a process which follows the transcription of DNA (Choice D). It is where mRNA is used as a template by ribosomes to synthesize polypeptides.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Which of the following best supports the idea that DNA is the universal genetic material in living organisms?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ All organisms have the same number of chromosomes
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ All organisms translate proteins using ribosomes
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ All organisms use DNA to pass on genetic information
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ All organisms reproduce sexually
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because the use of DNA is universal across all living organisms.
Choice A is incorrect because chromosome number varies widely across different species.
Choice B is true, but it is not a statement specific to DNA being the genetic material.
Choice D is incorrect because not all organisms reproduce sexually.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
How does the genetic code provide evidence of universal common ancestry?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The genetic code of mitochondria is identical to the genetic code of the nucleus in eukaryotes.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Each amino acid is coded for by only one codon.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Mutations cannot cause changes in the sequence of bases in the genome.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The genetic code is the same across all three domains of life, with just a few exceptions.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The genetic code is largely the same in all known organisms. There are a few exceptions such as mitochondrial DNA which can vary slightly in codon assignments for specific amino acids, and some bacterial species. Therefore Choice D is correct .
Choice A is incorrect because the genetic code used in mitochondria is similar to the genetic code used in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells but not entirely the same. Choice B is incorrect because the genetic code is degenerate. There are 64 possible codons in the genetic code, but only 20 amino acids. As a result, some amino acids are coded for by more than one codon, providing redundancy and flexibility in protein synthesis. Choice C is incorrect because mutations are changes in the genetic code. As a result, mutations play a significant role in generating genetic diversity and are a driving force in the process of evolution.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Which statement explains why DNA is evidence of common ancestry?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ All organisms have an identical DNA base sequence.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ All organisms contain DNA.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Closely related species contain the same alleles.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ More recently evolved species have more similar DNA.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because the presence of DNA in all organisms reflects a universal lineage, providing evidence of common ancestry. All organisms use the same four nucleotides (adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine) and the same genetic code to translate DNA into proteins, which supports the idea of a shared evolutionary origin.
Choice A is incorrect because while all organisms share common sequences in their DNA, their base sequences are not identical. Differences in DNA sequences accumulate over time, and species with more recent common ancestors have more similar DNA.
Choice C is incorrect because organisms that are closely related share many similarities in their DNA but their alleles are not all identical.
Choice D is incorrect because all organisms, living and extinct, contain DNA, not only recently evolved species.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Which of the following shows the correct structure of a DNA nucleotide?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/22716090-ebb2-445b-8107-c2459a247ff8/images/9ab33f74-e805-4dfb-838b-794a9ffbf1db/BI1394ii.png)

Choice B is correct because it shows the nitrogenous base bonded to the 1’ carbon of the pentose sugar and the phosphate bonded to the 5’ carbon. Even though the structure is inverted the bonding remains accurate, as this is how it would appear on the antiparallel DNA strand.
Choice A  is incorrect because it shows the phosphate bonded to the oxygen on the pentose sugar, which is not possible. Choice C is incorrect as it shows incorrect bonding for the nucleotide base, which is attached to the 2’ carbon. The phosphate is shown bonded to the 3’ end of the sugar, which would be part of the next nucleotide subunit. Choice D is incorrect as it shows incorrect bonding for the nucleotide base, again connected to the 2’ carbon.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Which set of bonds found in nucleic acids are correctly identified in the table below?

Bonds between phosphates and pentose sugarsBonds between nucleotide basesA.$\hspace{1em}$CovalentHydrogenB.$\hspace{1em}$HydrogenCovalentC.$\hspace{1em}$CovalentCovalentD.$\hspace{1em}$HydrogenHydrogen
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because the nucleic acid backbone is held together by covalently bonded sugars and phosphates, while the nucleotide bases are held together by hydrogen bonds.
Choice B is incorrect because the types of bonds are reversed. Choice C is incorrect because the bonds between nucleotides are hydrogen bonds, not covalent bonds. Choice D is incorrect because the bonds between phosphates and pentose sugars are covalent, not hydrogen bonds.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The diagram shows the structure of a DNA fragment.
Which letter points to the bonds that easily break and reform?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a626ffc3-c2e5-4f07-aa13-46af1143e26b/images/b46d0542-b068-4146-8497-4b93a1868de1/BI0038.png)

[Source: Adapted from User: Madprime. (2010, March). File: DNA chemical structure jp.svg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 15, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: DNA_chemical_structure_jp.svg. Copyright under CC-SA 3.0]
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The bonds between the nitrogenous bases holding the two strands together are hydrogen bonds. Hydrogen bonds typically break and reform easily; therefore  Choice B is the correct answer to the question.
The nitrogenous bases consist of single and double covalent bonds (Choice A) between nitrogen and carbon atoms. Deoxyribose sugars have single covalent bonds (Choice C) between the carbon atoms forming the pentose sugar. There are covalent bonds between the phosphate and sugar and between the phosphate and base (Choice D). Covalent bonds do not typically break and reform easily.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Which of the following molecules are classified as nucleic acids?


- I.ATPII.rRNAIII.DNA




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is false. ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is a nucleotide, not a nucleic acid. It is a single molecule, not a long chain (polymer) of nucleotides, which is what defines nucleic acids like DNA and RNA. 
Statement II is true. Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is a type of RNA, which is one of the two major types of nucleic acids (the other being DNA). It is a polymer of ribonucleotides, synthesised during transcription, and plays a role in protein synthesis. 
Statement III is true. DNA is a polymer of deoxyribonucleotides. It serves as the hereditary material in most organisms.
Note that the correct answer includes the two molecules whose names end in ‘NA’, which stands for nucleic acid - DNA and RNA.
Choice C is, therefore, the correct answer as it only includes the two true Statements II and III.
Choices A, B and D are incorrect as they include the false Statement I.

$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$:

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
What characteristic of DNA allows it to serve as a template for both DNA replication and mRNA synthesis?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The genetic code in DNA is universal across all organisms
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Hydrogen bonding enables the correct alignment of deoxyribonucleotides and ribonucleotides in newly synthesised strands
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ DNA’s double helix structure means one strand can be replicated at the same time as the other is being transcribed
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The strong sugar-phosphate backbone
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct. During both replication and transcription, nucleotides are aligned along the DNA template strand according to base-pairing rules. Hydrogen bonds form between the nitrogenous bases of the template DNA strand and the incoming deoxyribonucleotides (during replication) or ribonucleotides (in transcription).
The genetic code being universal means that the same codons code for the same amino acids in all organisms. However, this relates to protein synthesis, not to how DNA acts as a template for replication or transcription; Choice A is incorrect.
Choice C is incorrect because replication and transcription can’t occur on opposite strands simultaneously. 
Choice D is incorrect because while the sugar-phosphate backbone is a feature of both DNA and RNA strands that provides structural stability, it does not explain how DNA can interact with both DNA and RNA nucleotides.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Which of the following represents the correct structure of RNA?

A.$\hspace{2cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ac6dd223-2d74-4170-a8cf-7210719060f1/images/8671af0f-da99-480e-80ca-0fdf4b17f42b/BI1565A.png)

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because RNA is a single-stranded nucleic acid that contains adenine (A), cytosine (C), uracil (U), and guanine (G) nucleotide bases, while DNA is a double-stranded nucleic acid containing thymine (T) instead of uracil. The nucleotide bases are covalently bonded to a pentose sugar, which is covalently bonded to a phosphate at the 5’ and 3’ ends.
Choice A is incorrect as this is the structure of a DNA molecule, including a thymine base. Choice B is incorrect because RNA does not contain thymine. Choice D is incorrect because the diagram shows a double-stranded molecule similar to DNA,  but the strands are incorrectly depicted as parallel instead of the correct anti-parallel orientation.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Which of the following is the correct pairing of a nucleotide component and its description?

ComponentDescriptionA.$\hspace{1em}$SugarVaries between RNA and DNA to form genetic codeB.$\hspace{1em}$BaseProvides structure to the backboneC.$\hspace{1em}$PhosphateForms bonds with the base and sugarD.$\hspace{1em}$BaseVaries along nucleic acid to form genetic code
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because the sequence of nitrogenous bases is what encodes genetic information in DNA and RNA. This is the only row with a fully correct and precise description.
Choice A is incorrect because, while the sugar differs between DNA (deoxyribose) and RNA (ribose), it does not form the genetic code. The code is carried in the base sequence, not the sugar.
Choice B is incorrect because Bases are not part of the backbone (which is made of sugar–phosphate units). Bases project from the backbone and form the coding region, not the structure.
Choice C is incorrect because phosphate forms bonds with sugars, not with bases. Bases attach to the sugar (at carbon 1'), not to phosphate.

list.content:
The diagram below shows transcription.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b52a0f7e-44bc-41fb-b520-68f9f818e40a/images/7788d2fb-8bfa-4572-9a23-2786736e9a6e/BI0039.png)

What do structures X and Y have in common?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Both are made up of phosphate groups, ribose sugar and nitrogenous bases.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Both contain hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Both contain sugar-phosphate bonds between phosphate groups and monosaccharides.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Both have six-carbon monosaccharides in their structure.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Structure X is DNA, and structure Y is RNA. Both structures are made up of phosphate groups, sugars and nitrogenous bases. Both structures contain sugar-phosphate bonds, a type of covalent bond, between phosphate groups and sugars.
The sugar in DNA is deoxyribose and the sugar in RNA is ribose (Choice A). The sugar molecule in both DNA and RNA is a pentose sugar which means it has five carbon atoms, not six (Choice D).
RNA does not contain thymine (Choice B) and it is single-stranded.

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Refer to the diagram showing a section of a DNA strand.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cda96db5-d1f8-4821-bfb9-ddd33e4caa82/images/af63cd61-e4b6-436d-853c-27b1cbae8bda/Picture1.png)


[© Revision Village 2025. Created in BioRender.com]

Which carbon on the deoxyribose sugar is bonded to the phosphate group in the phosphodiester bond?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Carbon 1'
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Carbon 2'
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Carbon 3'
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Carbon 4'
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cda96db5-d1f8-4821-bfb9-ddd33e4caa82/images/a1f3dc2e-b1f0-4602-a55b-087562538587/ANS.png)


The phosphodiester bond forms between the 3' carbon of the sugar in one nucleotide (which has an –OH group), and the 5' phosphate group of the next nucleotide. So, the 3' carbon is directly involved in forming the bond that links nucleotides within a single strand of DNA or RNA, making Choice C correct.
The 1' carbon of the sugar is the attachment point for the nitrogenous base, not for the phosphate group; Choice A is incorrect.
In deoxyribose, the 2' carbon lacks an –OH group (it has just –H), distinguishing DNA from RNA.  It is not involved in bonding to phosphate, so Choice B is incorrect.
The 4' carbon connects to the 3' carbon and the 5' carbon within the sugar ring, but does not form bonds with the phosphate group; Choice D is incorrect.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Which of the following features of DNA most directly underpins its virtually limitless capacity to encode genetic information?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The use of four chemically distinct nitrogenous bases arranged in long chains.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Semiconservative replication via complementary base pairing, which preserves sequence diversity.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The covalent sugar-phosphate backbone’s antiparallel orientation, which fixes strand directionality.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Coiling of DNA into chromosomes, which aids efficient storage.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because the linear sequence of four different nucleotides (A, T, C and G) joined by phosphodiester bonds can form an almost infinite number of unique combinations, providing DNA with its enormous information-storage capacity. The human genome is about 3,000,000,000 nucleotides long, so there would be** $\mathbf{4^{3,000,000,000}}$ theoretical combinations of nucleotides.
Choice B is incorrect because complementary base pairing ensures faithful replication, but does not itself generate new sequences.
Choice C is incorrect because the antiparallel backbone ensures the strands are arranged in opposite directions, but does not contribute to the sequence diversity.
Choice D is incorrect because coiling allows DNA to be compacted and stored efficiently within the nucleus, but it does not directly contribute to the capacity to encode genetic information. While necessary for packaging long DNA molecules, coiling does not influence the number of unique sequences that DNA can carry or its ability to store diverse instructions.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
What bases are P, Q, and R if S is a pyrimidine?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f497fb1a-2df4-4043-a760-f2d78e9bc76a/images/3b6c2a4e-8c5c-4c00-a882-93d69b4c4568/BI0897A.png)


[© Revision Village 2023]

PQRA.$\hspace{1em}$$\hspace{1em}$ Guanine $\hspace{1em}$$\hspace{1em}$ Cytosine $\hspace{1em}$$\hspace{1em}$ Thymine $\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$GuanineAdenineCytosineC.$\hspace{1em}$CytosineGuanineAdenineD.$\hspace{1em}$AdenineThymineCytosine
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Adenine and guanine are purines. Cytosine and thymine are pyrimidines.
If S is a pyrimidine (~20%), it is either cytosine or thymine. Purines pair with pyrimidines, so Q, which also makes up about 20% of the molecule, must be guanine or adenine. This means Choices A and D can be eliminated as correct answers.
P and R must pair up as they make up approximately the same proportion of the DNA. So P and R must either be adenine and thymine or guanine and cytosine. This means Choice C is incorrect.
This leaves us with the correct answer of Choice B.  P is guanine, which pairs with R, cytosine, and Q is adenine, which pairs with S, which must be thymine.

list.title: Question 26
list.content: DNA and RNA are nucleic acids that are essential to all living organisms. ATP is a type of nucleotide. - Distinguish between ATP and the monomers of DNA in humans. [3] - Outline the roles of the different types of RNA involved in translation. [4] - Describe the structure of the DNA double helix. [8]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ ATP contains three phosphate groups WHEREAS each DNA nucleotide contains only one phosphate group [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP has adenine for a nitrogenous base WHEREAS a DNA nucleotide can contain adenine, cytosine, guanine or thymine [1] $\ce{ -> }$ a component of ATP is ribose WHEREAS DNA nucleotides have deoxyribose instead [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP stores energy OR provides energy, WHEREAS DNA carries OR transmits genetic information [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP can perform its function as a single monomer WHEREAS DNA can only perform its function, OR carry genetic material as a polymer [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP is found throughout the cell OR primarily in the cytoplasm OR mitochondria WHEREAS DNA is found primarily in the nucleus OR only found in the nucleus AND mitochondria [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both ATP and DNA molecules are nucleic acids which contain a phosphate group, a sugar and a base. The structural difference between a molecule of ATP and a molecule of DNA is that one ATP molecule contains three phosphate groups whereas one DNA nucleotide contains one phosphate group ($\checkmark$). In addition, the nitrogenous base in ATP is adenine whereas there are four possible nitrogenous bases in one nucleotide of DNA which are adenine, cytosine, guanine and thymine ($\checkmark$). The functional difference is that ATP stores energy, whereas DNA carries genetic material ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following (there must be at least one statement for each of mRNA, tRNA and rRNA to achieve maximum marks): $\ce{ -> }$ mRNA carries the genetic information from DNA to the ribosome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mRNA serves as a template for protein synthesis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ codons of mRNA specify positioning of amino acids along polypeptide OR codons guide the assembly of amino acids into a polypeptide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ tRNA molecules carry amino acids to mRNA OR ribosome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ anticodons on tRNA complementary to codons on mRNA allow amino acids to be positioned correctly along the polypeptide OR anticodons bind to codons to bring corresponding amino acid to the ribosome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rRNA provides the ribosome's structural framework OR forms ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rRNA catalyses the formation of peptide bonds between adjacent amino acids [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rRNA facilitates binding of mRNA and tRNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA orchestrate protein synthesis during translation [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Together, mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA orchestrate the process of protein synthesis ($\checkmark$) during translation. mRNA carries the genetic information from DNA to the ribosome ($\checkmark$). Codons on the mRNA specify the positioning of amino acids along the polypeptide chain ($\checkmark$). Each tRNA molecule has a specific anticodon sequence that is complementary to a codon on the mRNA ($\checkmark$). This base-pairing specificity allows tRNA to bring the corresponding amino acid to the correct position to form the polypeptide ($\checkmark$). The rRNA catalyses the formation of peptide bonds between adjacent amino acids ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: (appropriately labelled and correctly drawn DNA segment can be used in the answer) $\ce{ -> }$ each strand of DNA is a polymer of nucleotides [1] $\ce{ -> }$ each strand has a sugar-phosphate backbone [1] $\ce{ -> }$ four nitrogenous bases A OR adenine AND T OR thymine AND C OR cytosine AND G OR guanine [1] $\ce{ -> }$ two strands are anti-parallel OR parallel but in opposite directions OR one strand is in the 5’ to 3’ direction and the other strand is in the 3’ to 5’ direction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ strands are twisted OR right-handed and turn into a double helix with around 10 base pairs per turn [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nucleotides consist of one phosphate group, one deoxyribose sugar and one nitrogenous base [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phosphate group is bound to the 5’ carbon of the sugar OR deoxyribose OR pentose [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phosphate group is bound to the 3’ carbon OH group of deoxyribose (of the next nucleotide) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ covalent OR phosphodiester bond between phosphate and the sugar [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nitrogenous base OR base is bound to the 1’ carbon of the sugar OR deoxyribose OR pentose sugar [1] $\ce{ -> }$ covalent bond between nitrogenous base and deoxyribose OR sugar OR pentose sugar [1] $\ce{ -> }$ two strands are held together by hydrogen bonds between nitrogen bases of two nucleotides OR 3 hydrogen bonds between guanine and cytosine OR 2 hydrogen bonds between adenine and thymine [1] $\ce{ -> }$ complementary base pairing between nitrogenous bases [1] $\ce{ -> }$ A pairs up with T AND C pairs up with G [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: DNA is a nucleic acid, also known as a polymer of nucleotides ($\checkmark$) . Many nucleotides are joined together to form it. One nucleotide consists of three parts; a phosphate group, deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base ($\checkmark$). One end of the phosphate group is bonded to the 5’ carbon of the deoxyribose sugar ($\checkmark$). On the other side of the nucleotide, the phosphate group is bonded to the 3’ carbon sugar ($\checkmark$) of another nucleotide. Both bonds are covalent phosphodiester bonds ($\checkmark$). Repeated alternating sugar-phosphate bonds form the sugar-phosphate backbone ($\checkmark$). The 1’ carbon of the sugar is covalently bonded to the nitrogenous base ($\checkmark$) also through a condensation reaction to make up one complete nucleotide. DNA is a double helix ($\checkmark$) in which nitrogenous bases form the centre of the structure, and both strands are held together by hydrogen bonds ($\checkmark$) between the complementary bases from each strand. A pairs up with T, and C always pairs up with G ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.content:
The graph below shows the results of an experiment conducted by a team of researchers investigating the relationship between the composition and melting point of different DNA samples. At the melting point, the DNA double helix separates into two individual strands.
Two DNA samples were compared, one consisting of only PQ pairs and another one consisting of only RS pairs.  Letters P, Q, R and S represent different nitrogenous bases found in the DNA.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d59dd324-98c9-4e4e-91b6-758d5679701c/images/0881eea3-e69e-45cc-ad3b-7c9e377763b5/BI0321.png)


[ © Revision Village 2022]

Based on the results presented in the graph, and your knowledge of nucleotide base pairing (between purines and pyrimidines), deduce which nitrogenous bases correspond to the letters P, Q, R and S.
$\hspace{2.5em}$ P $\hspace{2.5em}$$\hspace{2.5em}$ Q $\hspace{2.5em}$$\hspace{2.5em}$ R $\hspace{2.5em}$$\hspace{2.5em}$ S $\hspace{2.5em}$$\hspace{1.5em}$ A. $\hspace{1.5em}$CytosineGuanineThymineAdenine$\hspace{1.5em}$ B. $\hspace{1.5em}$AdenineCytosineGuanineThymine$\hspace{1.5em}$ C. $\hspace{1.5em}$GuanineAdenineThymineCytosine$\hspace{1.5em}$ D. $\hspace{1.5em}$ThymineAdenineCytosineGuanine
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Adenine pairs up with thymine and cytosine pairs up with guanine. Hence, PQ or RS would either be adenine with thymine or cytosine with guanine (Choices A and D), but definitely not Choices B or C.
Cytosine and guanine pairing has three hydrogen bonds, whereas the adenine and thymine pairing has only two hydrogen bonds. At $95^oC$, there is a smaller percentage of RS-rich DNA melted content compared to PQ-rich DNA.
This shows that RS would be cytosine and guanine pairing (Choice D) and PQ is adenine and thymine. Because the extra hydrogen bond between C and G makes it more temperature resistant compared to A and T.
